title: Nanoparticle Vaccine Prevents Cancer in Mice
summary: A new nanoparticle vaccine has shown promise in preventing cancer in mice. The vaccine uses nanoparticles to deliver a cancer-fighting protein to the body. While the results are encouraging, further research is needed to test its efficacy in humans.

title: Study Explores Nutritional Value of Hemp Roots, Microgreens, and Leaves
summary: A recent study has examined the nutritional value of hemp roots, microgreens, and leaves. The research highlights the potential health benefits of these hemp-derived products. The findings suggest that they could be used as a nutritious food source.

title: Cells Linked to Depression Discovered
summary: Researchers have discovered cells that are linked to depression. The study provides new insights into the underlying mechanisms of depression and could lead to the development of more effective treatments. Further research is needed to confirm the findings.

title: Diet and Lifestyle Changes Cut Diabetes Risk
summary: A recent study has found that diet and lifestyle changes can significantly reduce the risk of developing diabetes. The research emphasizes the importance of a healthy lifestyle in preventing the disease. The findings suggest that simple changes to diet and exercise can have a major impact.

title: Long-Term Benefit of Adjuvant Therapy in Endometrial Cancer Patients
summary: New research has shown that adjuvant therapy can provide long-term benefits for patients with endometrial cancer. The study highlights the importance of adjuvant therapy in improving patient outcomes. Further research is needed to confirm the findings.

title: Prostate Cancer: A Deadly Disease
summary: Prostate cancer is a significant health concern for men. Recent research has highlighted the importance of early detection and treatment. The study emphasizes the need for men to be aware of the risks and symptoms of prostate cancer.

title: Common Hair Loss Drug Linked to Depression, Suicide
summary: A popular hair loss drug has been linked to an increased risk of depression and suicide. The study highlights the importance of monitoring patients taking the drug for potential side effects. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms.

title: Hormone Replacement Therapy Restores Healthy Immune Response
summary: A new study found that hormone replacement therapy can restore a healthy immune response in patients with immune disorders.

title: A Novel Cancer Treatment Reprograms Cell Death and Triggers Robust Immunity
summary: A new cancer treatment has been developed that reprograms cell death and triggers robust immunity, offering hope for patients with cancer.

title: Poor Sleep Linked to Faster Brain Aging
summary: Poor sleep may speed up brain aging, found a new study published in eBioMedicine.

title: Lymph Nodes Facilitate Cancer-Killing Immune Cells
summary: A new study found that lymph nodes play a crucial role in facilitating cancer-killing immune cells, providing a potential new target for cancer therapy.

title: A Cysteine-Rich Diet is Shown to Boost Intestinal Regeneration
summary: A new study reported in Nature has determined that the amino acid cysteine could promote regeneration among cells in the intestine.

title: Researchers Reveal Autoimmune Response in Patients with ALS
summary: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease, is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the nerve cells.

title: Scientists Reveal Nanoplastics Dysregulate Brain Cells
summary: A new study has found that nanoplastics can dysregulate brain cells, leading to potential neurological problems.

title: Scientists Reveal Immune Cells Drive Tumor Progression
summary: Researchers discovered that certain immune cells can drive tumor progression, highlighting the complex role of the immune system in cancer.

title: Combination Therapy Overcomes Glioblastoma Resistance
summary: A new study found that a combination therapy can overcome resistance to glioblastoma treatment, offering hope for patients with this aggressive form of brain cancer.

title: Novel Biomarkers Revealed for Pediatric Germ Tumors
summary: A new study identified novel biomarkers for pediatric germ tumors, which could lead to improved diagnosis and treatment of these rare cancers.

title: Unveiling the Mechanism of Chemo-Brain
summary: Researchers uncovered the mechanism behind chemo-brain, a common side effect of chemotherapy, which could lead to the development of new treatments.

summary: Introduction Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in sexually transmitted infections (STIs) now poses a significant and escalating threat to global health.

title: How a Bacterium Got More Dangerous After Defending Against a Virus
summary: Some viruses, known as bacteriophages, only infect bacterial cells, often destroying those bacteria in the process. Bacteria have developed ways to defend against these viruses.

summary: Influenza is a very contagious virus that can spread easily ... but one way to prevent the spread of illness is to isolate the virus.

title: The importance of Differential Diagnosis in Respiratory MDx
summary: Molecular Respiratory Panels — Importance of Differential Diagnosis With Respiratory Season rapidly approaching, it is essential to consider the importance of differential diagnosis in respiratory molecular diagnostic testing.

title: A Component of Mucus Can Stop Salmonella Infections
summary: Mucus isn't just some junk for tissues, it serves important biological purposes. It is an important line of defense, and researchers have found that a component of mucus can stop Salmonella infections.

title: Gut Immune Cells Migrate to Brain & Are Linked to Alzheimer's
summary: The gastrointestinal tract is the biggest immune organ in mammals.

title: 1 in 5 Young Adults Use Cannabis to Fall Asleep
summary: Over 20% of young adults report using cannabis or alcohol to help fall asleep

summary: How can cannabis legalization laws impact opioid use?

summary: Chemotherapy, anti-cancer drugs that stop the growth of tumor cells, encompasses a wide variety of different agents

title: TBI in Older Adults Linked to Higher Rates of Dementia
summary: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) in older adults is linked to higher rates of dementia

title: Epigenetics Links Maternal Infections & Neurodevelopmental Conditions
summary: There is increasing evidence linking maternal infections to developmental issues, and new research can explain how they are connected. The study explores the role of epigenetics in linking maternal infections to neurodevelopmental conditions.

title: Study Explores Role of Cannabinoid Receptor Type 2 Activity in Granulocyte Colony-Stimulating Factor (G-CSF) Treatment for Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)
summary: A study published in the Journal of Cannabis Research examined the effect of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) treatment on traumatic brain injury (TBI).

title: Acetaminophen Under the Microscope: Evidence from Peer-Reviewed Studies
summary: Acetaminophen is a common pain and fever reliever medication used for many ailments, including headaches, muscle aches, and fever. A study examines the evidence from peer-reviewed studies on acetaminophen.

title: Any Amount of Alcohol Consumption Increases Dementia Risk
summary: Drinking any quantity of alcohol is linked to a higher risk of dementia. A study found that there is no safe level of alcohol consumption when it comes to dementia risk.

title: New Huntington's Disease Therapy Slows Patients' Disease by 75%
summary: Huntington's disease is a fatal genetic disorder, but new work could help change that. A therapy has been found to slow the progression of the disease by 75%.

title: Study Reveals Foods That Delay Dementia and Heart Disease
summary: A new study identifies specific foods that can help delay the onset of dementia and heart disease, providing valuable insights into preventive measures.

title: Ultra-Processed Foods Drive Overeating
summary: A recent study shows that ultra-processed foods contribute to overeating, potentially leading to obesity and related health issues.

title: Esophageal Cancer Screening Inadequate for High-Risk Barrett's Esophagus Patients
summary: Practical strategies to screen for cancer remain a high priority for public health. For all types of cancer

summary: 3D cell cultures are no longer a futuristic idea. They’re already reshaping how we study diseases like cancer, off

summary: The host cell system is a critical determinant of recombinant protein quality and yield, with direct influence on protei

title: Simplified guide to ion exchange chromatography
summary: Ion exchange chromatography (IEX) is a versatile and widely used technique for separating biomolecules based on charge.

summary: A study published in the Clinical Toxicology examined ocular measures as evidence of cannabis-induced impairment and fou

title: 2-in-1 Inhaler Slashes Asthma Attacks in Children by 45%
summary: A new study found that a 2-in-1 anti-inflammatory inhaler reduced asthma attacks in children by 45% compared to the wide

title: Common Drug Effective in Patients Hospitalized with COVID-19
summary: Heparin, a widely available drug traditionally used to treat blood clots, lowers risk of death and ventilation in patien

title: Even for elite athletes, the body’s metabolism has its limits
summary: While ultramarathoners are capable of huge energy spurts, overall the athletes top out at 2.5 times the metabolic rate needed for basic body functions.

title: You’re probably eating enough protein, but maybe not the right mix
summary: Protein is having a moment. But even if most people are eating enough protein, studies suggest they may not be eating the right mix.

title: Are ultraprocessed foods truly addictive?
summary: Ultraprocessed foods can create powerful pulls similar to those of alcohol, nicotine or opioids, with worrisome consequences for our health.

title: Finding immune cells that stop a body from attacking itself wins medicine Nobel
summary: Shimon Sakaguchi discovered T-reg immune cells. Mary Brunkow and Fred Ramsdell identified the cells’ role in autoimmune disease.

title: New oral GLP-1 drugs could offer more options for weight loss
summary: GLP-1 injections use needles and require refrigeration. Pills that work in a similar way could be a cheaper, simpler solution.

title: Can AI spot harmful health side effects on social media?
summary: A new AI tool discovers harmful side effects of cannabis products from Reddit posts. Public health workers could use this info to help keep people safe.

title: Scientists made human egg cells from skin cells
summary: More work needs to be done to create viable human embryos, but the method might someday be used in IVF to help infertile people and male couples.

title: Cancer uses mitochondria to reprogram neighboring cells
summary: Cancer cells transfer mitochondria through nanotubes to healthy neighboring cells, turning them into tumor-supporting accomplices, a new study shows.

title: More young U.S. adults report trouble with memory and focus
summary: From 2013 to 2023, the prevalence of self-reported difficulties with memory, concentration and decision-making nearly doubled among young adults.

title: Pasteurization destroys H5N1 bird flu in milk
summary: Tests show pasteurized dairy with H5N1 remnants did not cause illness in mice, supporting safety of milk during outbreaks.

title: Your DNA may shape how you use cannabis
summary: A major collaboration between UC San Diego and 23andMe identified genes that shape cannabis use behaviors.

title: These 80-year-olds have the memory of 50-year-olds. Scientists finally know why
summary: SuperAgers defy normal aging by keeping sharp memories and healthy brains well into their 80s.

title: Stanford scientists grow thousands of mini human brains using common food additive
summary: Stanford scientists have solved a long-standing challenge in growing brain organoids by using a simple food additive to keep them from sticking together.

title: From poison to power: How lead exposure helped shape human intelligence
summary: Long before humans built cities or wrote words, our ancestors may have faced a hidden threat that shaped who we became.

title: Tiny brain nanotubes found by Johns Hopkins may spread Alzheimer’s
summary: Johns Hopkins scientists uncovered microscopic “nanotube” channels that neurons use to transfer toxic molecules.

title: Scientists find the brain’s hidden pulse that may predict Alzheimer’s
summary: Researchers at USC have created the first method to noninvasively measure microscopic blood vessel pulses in the human brain.

title: Supercharged vitamin k could help the brain heal itself
summary: Researchers have synthesized enhanced vitamin K analogues that outperform natural vitamin K in promoting neuron growth.

title: Scientists build artificial neurons that work like real ones
summary: UMass Amherst engineers have built an artificial neuron powered by bacterial protein nanowires that functions like a real one, but at extremely low voltage.

title: Dolphins may be getting Alzheimer’s from toxic ocean blooms
summary: Dolphins washing up on Florida’s shores may be victims of the same kind of brain degeneration seen in humans with Alzheimer’s disease.

title: Breakthrough compounds may reverse nerve damage caused by multiple sclerosis
summary: Researchers have identified two compounds, K102 and K110, that could repair the nerve damage from multiple sclerosis.

title: For the first time, scientists pinpoint brain cells linked to depression
summary: Scientists identified two types of brain cells, neurons and microglia, that are altered in people with depression. Through genomic mapping of post-mortem brain tissue, they found major differences in gene activity affecting mood and inflammation.

title: Scientists discover brain circuit that can switch off chronic pain
summary: Scientists have pinpointed Y1 receptor neurons in the brain that can override chronic pain signals when survival instincts like hunger or fear take precedence.

title: Scientists suggest the brain may work best with 7 senses, not just 5
summary: Scientists at Skoltech developed a new mathematical model of memory that explores how information is encoded and stored. Their analysis suggests that memory works best in a seven-dimensional conceptual space — equivalent to having seven senses.

title: Scientists just found a molecule that could stop Parkinson’s in its tracks
summary: Researchers have designed a peptide that prevents the deadly misfolding of alpha-synuclein, the protein behind Parkinson’s and some dementias.

title: Scientists finally reveal what’s behind long COVID’s mysterious brain fog
summary: Researchers in Japan have pinpointed a biological cause of Long COVID brain fog using advanced PET brain imaging. They discovered widespread increases in AMPA receptor density linked to cognitive impairment and inflammation.

title: Scientists find brain circuit that traps alcohol users in the vicious cycle of addiction
summary: Addiction often isn’t about chasing pleasure—it’s about escaping pain. Researchers at Scripps Research have discovered that a tiny brain region called the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus (PVT) becomes hyperactive when animals learn that alcohol eases the agony of withdrawal.

title: Scientists find hidden brain damage behind dementia
summary: A University of New Mexico scientist is revealing what might be one of the most overlooked causes of dementia — damage in the brain’s tiny blood vessels. Dr. Elaine Bearer has created a new way to classify these changes, showing that many people diagnosed with Alzheimer’s also suffer from vascular damage that quietly destroys brain tissue.

title: Why ultra-processed foods aren’t the real villain behind overeating
summary: Researchers from Leeds found that overeating is driven more by what people believe about food than by its actual ingredients or level of processing. Foods perceived as fatty, sweet, or highly processed were more likely to trigger indulgence.

title: Brain cancer that eats the skull stuns scientists
summary: A new study shows glioblastoma isn’t confined to the brain—it erodes the skull and hijacks the immune system within skull marrow.

title: How this odd-looking animal outsmarted aging
summary: Naked mole-rats seem to have found nature’s cheat code for longevity. Scientists discovered that small tweaks in one of their proteins make it better at fixing DNA damage, helping the animals resist aging.

title: Scientists finally read the hidden DNA code that shapes disease
summary: EMBL researchers created SDR-seq, a next-generation tool that decodes both DNA and RNA from the same cell. It finally opens access to non-coding regions, where most disease-associated genetic variants lie.

title: Scientists just found real teeth growing on a fish’s head
summary: Scientists discovered true teeth growing on the head of the spotted ratfish, a distant shark relative. The toothed structure, called a tenaculum, helps males hold onto females during mating.

title: Decades-old photosynthesis mystery finally solved
summary: Scientists from the Indian Institute of Science (IISc) and Caltech have finally solved a decades-old mystery about how photosynthesis really begins.

title: They’re smaller than dust, but crucial for Earth’s climate
summary: Coccolithophores, tiny planktonic architects of Earth’s climate, capture carbon, produce oxygen, and leave behind geological records that chronicle our planet’s history.

title: It’s not just genes — parents can pass down longevity another way
summary: Scientists studying tiny roundworms have uncovered how the secrets of a long life can be passed from parents to their offspring — without changing DNA.

title: Before they sucked blood, leeches were ocean hunters
summary: A 430-million-year-old fossil has rewritten leech history, showing they are at least 200 million years older than previously believed.

title: Saturn’s icy moon Enceladus just revealed stunning new clues to life
summary: Fresh analysis of Cassini data has revealed new complex organic molecules inside ice grains spewing from Enceladus.

title: The billion-year reign of fungi that predated plants and made Earth livable
summary: Fungi may have shaped Earth’s landscapes long before plants appeared.

title: Cancer patients who got a COVID vaccine lived much longer
summary: A groundbreaking study reveals that cancer patients who received a COVID-19 mRNA vaccine within 100 days of starting immunotherapy lived dramatically longer than those who didn’t.

title: This experimental “super vaccine” stopped cancer cold in the lab
summary: UMass Amherst researchers have developed a groundbreaking nanoparticle-based cancer vaccine that prevented melanoma, pancreatic, and triple-negative breast cancers in mice—with up to 88% remaining tumor-free.

title: Thousands fall ill as mosquito fever explodes across southern China
summary: China’s Guangdong Province is battling its worst-ever chikungunya outbreak, with thousands of infections spreading across major cities and nearby regions.

title: Nanotech transforms vinegar into a lifesaving superbug killer
summary: Researchers have enhanced vinegar’s antibacterial properties by infusing it with cobalt-based carbon nanoparticles.

title: A flu test you can chew
summary: Flu detection could soon be as simple as chewing gum.

title: Millions could be living with hidden smell loss after COVID without knowing
summary: A massive NIH-backed study reveals that COVID-19’s toll on smell may be more widespread and lasting than most realize.
